meaning: To simplify integration, the syslog message format is used as a transport mechanism. This applies a common prefix to each message, containing the date and hostname.
To simplify integration, the syslog message format is used as a transport mechanism. This applies a common prefix to each message, containing the date and hostname.
Version is an integer and identifies the version of the CEF format.
Device Vendor is a string and identifies the vendor of sending device.
Device Product is a string and identifies the product of sending device.
Device Version is a string and identifies the version of sending device.
Signature ID is a unique identifier per event-type
Name is a string representing a human-readable and understandable description of the event.
Severity is an integer and reflects the importance of the event.
Action mentioned in the event.
Application level protocol, example values are: HTTP, HTTPS, SSHv2, Telnet, POP, IMAP, IMAPS, etc.
Represents the category assigned by the originating device. Devices oftentimes use their own categorization schema to classify events.
One of four IPv6 address fields available to map fields that do not apply to any other in this dictionary
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.

There are three number fields available which can be used to map fields which do not fit into any other field of this dictionary. If possible, these fields should not be used, but a more specific field from the dictionary. Also check the guidelines hereafter for hints on how to utilize these fields.

A count associated with this event. How many times was this same event observed?

The DNS domain part of the complete fully qualified domain name (FQDN).
The service which is targeted by this event.
Identifies the translated destination that the event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
Port after it was translated; for example, a firewall. Valid port numbers are 0 to 65535.

There are two timestamp fields available which can be used to map fields which do not fit into any other field of this dictionary. If possible, these fields should not be used, but a more specific field from the dictionary. Also check the guidelines later in this document for hints about utilizing these fields.

There are two timestamp fields available which can be used to map fields which do not fit into any other field of this dictionary. If possible, these fields should not be used, but a more specific field from the dictionary. Also check the guidelines later in this document for hints about utilizing these fields.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.
Any information about what direction the communication that was observed has taken.
The DNS domain part of the complete fully qualified domain name (FQDN).
A name that uniquely identifies the device generating this event.
The facility generating this event. Syslog for example has an explicit facility associated with every event.
Interface on which the packet or data entered the device.
The Windows domain name of the device address.
Interface on which the packet or data left the device.
Unique identifier for the payload associated with the event.
Process name associated to the event. In UNIX, the process generating the syslog entry for example.
Identifies the translated device address that the event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
Identifies the destination that an event refers to in an IP network. The format should be a fully qualified domain name associated with the destination node, when a node is available. Examples:
Six colon-separated hexadecimal numbers. Example: "00:0D:60:AF:1B:61"
The Windows domain name of the destination address.
Provides the ID of the destination process associated with the event. For example, if an event contains process ID 105, "105" is the process ID.

The allowed values are: "Administrator", "User", and "Guest". It identifies the source user's privileges. In UNIX, for example, activity executed by the root user would be identified with sourceUserPrivileges of "Administrator". This is an idealized and simplified view on privileges and can be extended in the future.
The name of the process which is the event's destination. For example: "telnetd", or "sshd".
The valid port numbers are between 0 and 65535.
Identifies destination that the event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
The timezone for the device generating the event.
Identifies the destination user by ID. For example, in UNIX, the root user is generally associated with user ID 0.

Identifies the destination user by name. This is the user associated with the event's destination. E-mail addresses are also mapped into the UserName fields. The recipient is a candidate to put into destinationUserName.
Identifies the device that an event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
The format should be a fully qualified domain name associated with the device node, when a node is available. Examples:
Six colon-separated hexadecimal numbers. Example: "00:0D:60:AF:1B:61"
Provides the ID of the process on the device generating the event.
The time at which the activity Stamp related to the event ended. The format is MMM dd yyyy HH:mm:ss or milliseconds since epoch (Jan 1st 1970). An example would be reporting the end of a session.
An ID used by the originating device. Usually these are increasing numbers associated with events.
Time when file was created.
Hash of a file.
An ID associated with a file could be the inode.
Time when file was last modified.
Full path to the file, including file name itself.
Permissions of the file.
Type of file (pipe, socket, etc.)

A timestamp field available to map a timestamp that does not apply to any other defined timestamp field in this dictionary. Use all flex fields sparingly and seek a more specific, dictionary supplied field when possible. These fields are typically reserved for customer use and should not be set by vendors unless necessary.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.

One of two number fields available to map Long data that does not apply to any other field in this dictionary. Use sparingly and seek a more specific, dictionary supplied field when possible. These fields are typically reserved for customer use and should not be set by vendors unless necessary.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.

One of two number fields available to map Long data that does not apply to any other field in this dictionary. Use sparingly and seek a more specific, dictionary supplied field when possible. These fields are typically reserved for customer use and should not be set by vendors unless necessary.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.

One of two string fields available to map String data that does not apply to any other field in this dictionary. Use sparingly and seek a more specific, dictionary supplied field when possible. These fields are typically reserved for customer use and should not be set by vendors unless necessary.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.

One of two string fields available to map String data that does not apply to any other field in this dictionary. Use sparingly and seek a more specific, dictionary supplied field when possible. These fields are typically reserved for customer use and should not be set by vendors unless necessary.
All custom fields have a corresponding label field. Each of these fields is a string and describes the purpose of the custom field.
Name of the file.
Size of the file.
Number of bytes transferred inbound. Inbound relative to the source to destination relationship, meaning that data was flowing from source to destination.
An arbitrary message giving more details about the event. Multi-line entries can be produced by using \n as the new-line separator.
Time when old file was created.
Hash of the old file.
An ID associated with the old file could be the inode.
Time when old file was last modified.
Name of the old file.
Full path to the old file, including file name itself.
Permissions of the old file.
Size of the old file.
Type of the old file (pipe, socket, etc.)
Number of bytes transferred outbound. Outbound relative to the source to destination relationship, meaning that data was flowing from destination to source.
Displays the outcome, usually as 'success' or 'failure'.
Identifies the Layer-4 protocol used. The possible values are protocol names such as TCP or UDP.
The reason an audit event was generated. For example "Bad password" or "Unknown User". This could also be an error or return code.  Example: "0x1234"
In the case of an HTTP request, this field contains the URL accessed. The URL should contain the protocol as well, e.g.,
The User-Agent associated with the request.
Description of the content from which the request originated (for example, HTTP Referrer).
Cookies associated with the request.
The method used to access a URL. Possible values: "POST", "GET", ...
The time at which the event related to the activity was received. The format is MMM dd yyyy HH:mm:ss or milliseconds since epoch (Jan 1st 1970).
Identifies the source that an event refers to in an IP network. The format should be a fully qualified domain name associated with the source node, when a node is available. Examples:
Six colon-separated hexadecimal numbers. Example: "00:0D:60:AF:1B:61"
The Windows domain name for the source address.
The DNS domain part of the complete fully qualified domain name (FQDN).
The service which is responsible for generating this event.
Identifies the translated source that the event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
Port after it was translated by for example a firewall. Valid port numbers are 0 to 65535.
The ID of the source process associated with the event.

The allowed values are: "Administrator", "User", and "Guest". It identifies the source user's privileges. In UNIX, for example, activity executed by the root user would be identified with sourceUserPrivileges of "Administrator". This is an idealized and simplified view on privileges and can be extended in the future.
The name of the event's source process.
The valid port numbers are 0 to 65535.
Identifies the source that an event refers to in an IP network. The format is an IPv4 address. Example: "192.168.10.1"
The time when the activity the event referred to started. The format is MMM dd yyyy HH:mm:ss or milliseconds since epoch (Jan 1st 1970).
Identifies the source user by ID. This is the user associated with the source of the event. For example, in UNIX, the root user is generally associated with user ID 0.
Identifies the source user by name. E-mail addresses are also mapped into the UserName fields. The sender is a candidate to put into sourceUserName.
0 means base event, 1 means aggregated, 2 means correlation, and 3 means action; this field can be omitted for base events (type 0)
The DNS domain name of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The IP address of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The hostname of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The agent ID of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The MAC address of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The time at which information about the event was received by the ArcSight connector.
The agent type of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The agent time zone of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The version of the ArcSight connector that processed the event.
The URI for the Translated Zone that the destination asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
The URI for the Zone that the destination asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
The URI for the Translated Zone that the device asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
The URI for the Zone that the device asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
The latitudinal value to which the destination’s IP address belongs.
The longitudinal value to which the destination’s IP address belongs.
This is a unique ID that ArcSight assigns to each event.
The URI for the Translated Zone that the destination asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
The URI for the Zone that the source asset has been assigned to in ArcSight.
